results.abstract: Justin Simien, the writer and director of the 1989-set horror-comedy, also wrote some of the retro-sounding songs. Though he’s known for “Dear White People,” music has long been a hobby.

results.title: The ‘Borat’ Sequel’s 3 Wildest Scenes: Here’s What Happens
results.abstract: Sacha Baron Cohen’s pranks involve political figures like Mike Pence and Rudy Giuliani, as well as one unexpected A-list celebrity.

results.abstract: In this spooky season, why not go out on a limb with these films off the beaten path? If you’re not up for creature features, we still have you covered.

results.title: ‘Now and Then’ at 25: Girlhood Finally Taken Seriously
results.abstract: This movie about inseparable tweens and the grown-ups they became was dismissed in 1995. Today it’s cherished by waves of new fans for the weight it gives their stories.

results.title: Want a Halloween Thriller as Daring as ‘Psycho’? Try ‘Peeping Tom’
results.abstract: Michael Powell’s disturbing chronicle of a murderous filmmaker was ahead of its time, influencing Martin Scorsese, Brian De Palma and Kathryn Bigelow.

multimedia.caption: Brenda Bruce as a victim caught in the cross-hairs of a viewfinder in “Peeping Tom” (1960), which, along with “Psycho” the same year, pushed the boundaries of the audience-screen relationship.

results.title: James Redford, Documentarian and Environmentalist, Dies at 58
results.abstract: After two liver transplants, he founded an institute to increase awareness. He and his father, Robert Redford, also championed environmental films.

results.title: Rudy Giuliani Denies He Did Anything Wrong in New ‘Borat’ Movie
results.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Neil Vigdor
results.abstract: President Trump’s personal lawyer has become caught up in Sacha Baron Cohen’s new “Borat” satire after he was shown with an actress in an edited scene.

results.title: Tony Todd on the Joy of ‘Candyman,’ and the Role of Black Horror
results.abstract: Frightening movies help fans gain a “new understanding,” says the veteran star of scary stories, including the new “Tales From the Hood 3.”

multimedia.copyright: Clifford Prince King for The New York Times
multimedia.caption: Despite his extensive theater background, Todd is known for horror movies, but he doesn’t mind: The genre is “passionately adored — so I don’t see it as a secondhand citizenship.”

results.abstract: Aaron Sorkin is only the latest filmmaker to dramatize this prime example of political theater. Each version has a different understanding of the case and what it means.
